Â§ 4.3 Prime & GCD's

Definition: Prime/Composite

  • An Integer p is a Prime if its only divisors are itself and 1

  • A composite is any number that is not a Prime

Theorem 4.3.1

Every integer has a unique prime factorization
n=p1a1âp2a2â¯pnann=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot p_{2}^{a_{2}}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}n=pâ1âaâ1âââââpâ2âaâ2âââââ¯pânâaânââââ

b) 3=3â13=3\cdot13=3â1

Theorem 4.3.3

If n is a composite number then âpâ¤n\exists p \leq \sqrt{n}âpâ¤âânâââ such that p is prime and pâ£np|npâ£n

proof:

Hence a>na>\sqrt{n}a>âânâââ and b>nb>\sqrt{n}b>âânâââ is false.

i.e. â(pâq)â¡âpââq\urcorner (p\bigwedge q)\equiv \urcorner p\bigvee \urcorner qâ(pâq)â¡âpââq

Otherwise, a is composite, by THM 4.3.1

and since is true that pi<aâ¤ap_{i}<a\leq\sqrt{a}pâiââ<aâ¤ââaâââ
\quad

=pi[p1a1â¯piaiâ1â¯pkak]âq\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad=p_{i}[p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdots p_{i}^{a_{i-1}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}]\cdot q=pâiââ[pâ1âaâ1âââââ¯pâiâaâiâ1âââââ¯pâkâaâkââââ]âq

Hence

Example 2

Show 61 is prime
Assume 61 is composite. By THM 4.3.2
âpâ¤161\exists{p}\leq\sqrt{161}âpâ¤ââ161âââ such that p is prime & divides 61.
pâ¤61â¤64=8p\leq\sqrt{61}\leq\sqrt{64}=8pâ¤ââ61ââââ¤ââ64âââ=8
Primes in range 1 - 8: 2,3,5,7
2â¤612\nmid612â¤61
3â¤613\nmid613â¤61
5â¤615\nmid615â¤61
7â¤617\nmid617â¤61
Hence
61 cannot be composite.
i.e. 61 is prime.

Algorithm For Prime Factorization: Trial Division Algorithm.

To find prime factorization of composite n,

  1. Divide n by successive primes beginning p=2p=2p=2.

  2. If n=pâkkâZn=p\cdot{k}\quad k\in\mathbb{Z}n=pâkkâZ, then
    \quadi) kkk is prime. â\rightarrowâdone
    \quadii) kkk is composite. â\rightarrowârepeat

Theorem 4.3.3

There are infinitely many Primes

Proof

Assume p1,p2,....,pnp_{1}, p_{2},...., p_{n}pâ1ââ,pâ2ââ,....,pânââ are all Primes i.e.i.e.i.e. finite number of Primes.
Construct Q=p1âp2â¯pn+1âZQ = p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} + 1 \in\mathbb{Z}Q=pâ1âââpâ2âââ¯pânââ+1âZ

Two possibilities:
i) QQQ is Composite


If Q is Composite then
Q=aâba,bâZQ = a\cdot{b}\quad a,b \in \mathbb{Z}Q=aâba,bâZ
By THM 4.3.1 aaa and bbb have unique Prime factorizations.
a=p1anâ¯pnana = p_{1}^{a_{n}}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}a=pâ1âaânâââââ¯pânâaânââââ
b=p1bnâ¯pnbnb = p_{1}^{b_{n}}\cdots p_{n}^{b_{n}}b=pâ1âbânâââââ¯pânâbânââââ

Hence

Qâp1âp2â¯pn=1Q-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} =1Qâpâ1âââpâ2âââ¯pânââ=1
aâbâp1âp2â¯pn=1a\cdot b-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} =1aâbâpâ1âââpâ2âââ¯pânââ=1
p1a1â¯pnan+bnâp1âp2âpn=1p_{1}^{a_1}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}+b_{n}}-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdot p_{n}=1pâ1âaâ1âââââ¯pânâaânââ+bânâââââpâ1âââpâ2âââpânââ=1
pi[p1a1+b1â¯piai+biâ1â¯pnan+bnâp1âp2â¯piâ1âpi+1âpn]=1p_{i}[p_{1}^{a_{1}+b_{1}} \cdots p_{i}^{a_{i}+b_{i}-1} \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}+b_{n}}-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{i-1}\cdot p_{i+1}\cdot p_{n}]=1pâiââ[pâ1âaâ1ââ+bâ1âââââ¯pâiâaâiââ+bâiâââ1âââ¯pânâaânââ+bânâââââpâ1âââpâ2âââ¯pâiâ1âââpâi+1âââpânââ]=1
piâq=1p_{i}\cdot q=1pâiâââq=1
âpiâ£1\Rightarrow p_{i}|1âpâiâââ£1 impossible pi>1p_{i}>1pâiââ>1. (prime)
âQ\Rightarrow QâQ is NOT composite.

Then,
ii) QQQ is prime. âa\Leftarrow aâa contradiction to existence of n primes.
Hence there are an infinite number of primes.

Cute fact:   
*Largest prime number discovered so far is (2^74207281) -1 in the year of 2016.
GIMPS - (Greate Internet Mersenne Prime Search) *
 
*Primes of the form (2^p)-1 are called Mersenne Primes. *
P - prime

Gcd's & LCM's

Definition GCD


The Greatest Common Divisor of a and b, denoted \quad
gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b) is the largest dâZd\in\mathbb{Z}dâZ such that dâ£ad|adâ£a and dâ£bd|bdâ£b

\quad

Example 4

a)a)a) gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12
b)b)b) gcd(17,22)=1gcd(17,22)=1gcd(17,22)=1 â\leftarrowâ relatively prime

\quad
Definition Pairwise-replatively prime
The integers a1,â¯,ana_{1},\cdots,a_{n}aâ1ââ,â¯,aânââ are Pairwise-replatively prime if gcd(ai,aj)=1gcd(a_{i},a{j})=1gcd(aâiââ,aj)=1
where 1â¤i<jâ¤n1\leq i < j \leq n1â¤i<jâ¤n

Example 5

a) 10, 17, 21

In general

4.3 Continued

\quad Since the trial Algorithm takes long, finding GCD of a, b is inefficient by means of prime factorization

Euclidean Algorithm
Suppose we wish to find gcd(24,12)gcd(24,12)gcd(24,12)
\quad 36=1â24+1236 = 1\cdot24+1236=1â24+12
\quad 24=2â12+024 =2\cdot12+024=2â12+0
\quad => The last nonzero remainder = GCD

Theorem 4.3.4

\quad Let a=bâq+ra=b\cdot q + ra=bâq+r a,b,q,râZ\qquad a,b,q,r \in \mathbb{Z}a,b,q,râZ
\quad\quad then gcd(a,b)gcd(a, b)gcd(a,b) = gdc(b,r)gdc(b,r)gdc(b,r)
\quad proof: goal  dâ£a\space d|a dâ£a ^  dâ£bâdâ£b \space d|b \leftrightarrow d|b ^\space dâ£bâdâ£bâ ââ ^  dâ£r\space d|r dâ£r
\quad\quad for any divisor dâZd\in \mathbb{Z}dâZ

\quad i.) Assume dâ£ad|adâ£a ^ dâ£bd|bdâ£b
\qquad a=kâbkâZa=k\cdot b \quad k\in \mathbb{Z}a=kâbkâZ
\qquad b=uâduâZb=u\cdot d \quad u\in \mathbb{Z}b=uâduâZ
a=bâq+r\qquad a = b\cdot q+ra=bâq+r
r=aâbâq\qquad r = a - b\cdot qr=aâbâq
   =kâdâuâdâq\qquad\space\space\space = k\cdot d - u\cdot d\cdot q   =kâdâuâdâq
r=d(kâuâq)\qquad r = d(k-u\cdot q)r=d(kâuâq)
r=dâv\qquad r = d\cdot vr=dâv
   =dâ£r\qquad\space\space\space = d|r   =dâ£r

\quad Now assume dâ£b d|b\spacedâ£b  ^  dâ£r\space d|r dâ£r
b=dâkkâZ\qquad b=d\cdot k \quad k\in \mathbb{Z}b=dâkkâZ
r=dâuuâZ\qquad r=d\cdot u \quad u\in \mathbb{Z}r=dâuuâZ
a=bâq+r\qquad\quad a = b\cdot q +ra=bâq+r
   =dâkâq+dâu\qquad\quad\space\space\space =d\cdot k\cdot q + d\cdot u   =dâkâq+dâu
   =a=dâv\qquad\quad\space\space\space = a = d\cdot v   =a=dâv
   =dâ£a\qquad\quad\space\space\space = d|a   =dâ£a

\quad Since the results hold for any divisor ddd, they are true in particular for the greatest common divisor
i.e.gcd(a,b)=gcd(b,r)\qquad i.e.\quad gcd(a,b) = gcd(b,r)i.e.gcd(a,b)=gcd(b,r)

Example 7

\quad Find the gcd of...
\quad a.) gcd(120,500)gcd(120,500)gcd(120,500)

Algorithm: GCD

gcd(x,y)\quad gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y)
a=max(x,y)\qquad a = max(x,y)a=max(x,y)
b=min(x,y)\qquad b = min(x,y)b=min(x,y)
r=a mod b\qquad r = a\space mod\space br=a mod b
while r != 0\qquad while\space r\space !=\space 0while r != 0
a=b\qquad\quad a=ba=b
b=r\qquad\quad b=rb=r
r=a mod b\qquad\quad r=a\space mod\space br=a mod b
return b\qquad return\space breturn b

4.4 Solving Congruences

\quad Linear Congruences
\quad goal: Solve
\qquad aâxâ¡b (mod m)a\cdot x \equiv b\space (mod\space m)aâxâ¡b (mod m)
\quad for xxx
\quad in algebra: aâx=ba\cdot x = baâx=b
\qquad\qquad\qquad x=bax=\frac{b}{a}x=âaââbââ

\quad Q: xâ¡ba(mod m)x \equiv \frac{b}{a}(mod\space m)xâ¡âaââbââ(mod m)
\quad A: Consider
